events.description: The South Korean won hit a two-week low against the US dollar due to structural capital outflows.
Global investment banks raised South Korea's 2026 growth outlook to 2.1%.

facts.fact_text: The South Korean won depreciated to around 1,464 per dollar.

evidences.evidence_text: The South Korean won depreciated to around 1,464 per dollar, erasing earlier-week gains to hit a two-week low

facts.fact_text: Overseas holdings by Korean retail investors reached nearly $171 billion as of January 29.

evidences.evidence_text: Overseas holdings hit nearly $171 billion as of January 29

facts.fact_text: Resident dollar deposits in South Korea reached a record $119.43 billion.

evidences.evidence_text: The shift toward foreign assets has also pushed resident dollar deposits to a record $119.43 billion

facts.fact_text: Eight major global investment banks raised South Korea’s 2026 growth outlook to 2.1%.

evidences.evidence_text: A KCIF report showed eight major global investment banks raised South Korea’s 2026 growth outlook to 2.1%

claims.claim_text: Structural capital outflows are driving the decline of the Korean won.

evidences.evidence_text: The decline reflects structural capital outflows, with Korean retail investors increasingly favouring US equities.

claims.claim_text: High resident dollar deposits are limiting the effectiveness of foreign exchange policy tools.

evidences.evidence_text: limiting the impact of FX policy tools despite solid economic fundamentals and equity market gains.

claims.claim_text: A rebound in the global semiconductor industry is the reason for the upgraded growth outlook.
claims.author: Global Investment Banks

evidences.evidence_text: citing a rebound in the global semiconductor industry.

evidence.evidence_text: a surge in US stock purchases has added further pressure.
citing a rebound in the global semiconductor industry.
limiting the impact of FX policy tools despite solid economic fundamentals
